msContents.summary: A 15th-century manuscript of the Cāndravyākaraṇa of the Buddhist grammarian Candragomin (probably 5th c. CE) with its most widespread and best known commentary, the Cāndravyākaraṇavṛtti, for a long time believed to be the work of Candragomin himself, but now generally attributed to an author called Dharmadāsa who probably flourished in the 6th c. CE, but of whom nothing else is known (Dash 1986; Oberlies 1989). The manuscript contains the whole of chapter 1 and part of chapter 2. The text stops abruptly at the end of f. 113r, in the middle of the commentary on sūtra 2.3.37, gaurādibhyaḥ, as if the copyist was interrupted and never had the chance to complete the task. Folio 113v was left blank, although two verses, probably of a devotional or apotropaic nature, were later added by a different hand. This manuscript is among those used by Bruno Liebich for his 1902 edition of the sūtrapāṭha.

msItem.title: Cāndravyākaraṇavṛtti
Cāndravṛtti
msItem.head: Main Text
Commentary
msItem.incipit: [1v1] siddhaṃ,, praṇamya,, sarvvajñaṃ,, sarvvīyaṃ,, jagato,, % gurum,, | laghu vispaṣṭasaṃpūrṇṇa,,m ucyate,, śabdalakṣaṇaṃ || atha kimartho varṇṇānām upadeśaḥ [1v2] pratyāharārthaḥ | pratyāhāro hi lāghavena śāstrapravṛttyarthaḥ ||
msItem.explicit: [112v6] || gaura ityevamādi[113r1]bhyaḥ striyāṃ ṅīṣ bhavati || gaurī śabalī | kalmāśī | śāraṅgī | % piśaṅgī | matsī | gaura | śabala | kalmāṣa | sāraṅga | piśaṅga | matsya | manuṣya | śṛ[113r2]ṅga | gavaya | haya | makara | ṛśya | ghaṭa | droṇa | druṇa | aroṣa | % daraṭa | aukaṭa | kaṇa | āmalaka | kuvalaya | badara | bimba | tarkāra | sāṣkāra | ṣaṣka[113r3]ṇḍa | suṣada | alinda | alaja | pāṇḍuṣa | āṭaka | āsanda | % sṛpāṭa | yaskula | sūrya | sūca | sūpa | mūṣa | dhātaka | śallaka | mālata | vetasa | [113r4] vṛsa | atasa | bhṛṅga | maha | vastra | maṭha | svan | kurukata | a%naḍuh | eṣaṇa karaṇa | dehana | kākānada | gavānada | tejana | lavaṇa | pāna | [113r5] seva | sotama | āyasthūna | bhauriki | bhauliki | auṅgatamā%ni | ālambi | ālaki | ālandhi | kālandhi | āraṭa | doṭa | nāṭa | -1-lāṭa |

supportDesc.foliation: Nepālākṣara letter-numerals, mid-left margin, verso (ff. 1v-112v). A flyleaf at the beginning bearing no number; the last folio also bears no number.

numerals for the units 1, 2, 3, 4 are annotated with the syllables śrī, dvi, tri respectively, added by a later hand next to the original numerals for most decades (11, 12, 13; 21, 22, 23; etc.), up to f. 91.
supportDesc.condition: Complete, although the text is left unfinished. The right margin of several leaves is worn out, and there are a few worm-holes, but with little loss of text. Some folios are smudged, but still legible.

layout.p: 6 lines per page, approximately 48 akṣaras per line.
layout.stringHole: One string hole in the middle of a blank column-like space. 2.5
layout.p: The end of the commentary to each sūtra is generally marked by a double daṇḍa, followed by a blank space roughly corresponding to the size of two akṣaras and another double daṇḍa. The end of a section rubric, whether a pāda or an adhyāya, is marked in the same way, but the blank space between the double daṇḍas, often highlighted with red paste, is wider, approximately corresponding to 3/4 akṣaras. The text is arranged in such a way that the initial part of the commentary to the first sūtra of each section is interrupted by a similar sequence (a blank space between double daṇḍas) of exactly the same length of the space left at the end of the section rubric occurring above it, thus making the internal articulation of the text visually conspicuous and easy to identify within the manuscript (see for example the end of chapter 1 and the beginning of chapter 2 on f. 73v). Moreover, the beginning of each section is marked by a siddham sign. Puṣpikās are occasionally used to mark the end of a section or certain folio numbers, such as 100.

handNote.desc: Hooked Nepālākṣarā (Bhujimol) in black ink (main text and corrections).
Several hands appear on the initial flyleaf, and on folios 1r and 113v.

physDesc.additions:
On both sides of the initial flyleaf, invocations to Śiva and Sarasvatī, as well as verses in vernacular or corrupt Sanskrit.
On the top left corner of 1r, a short note with the date Samvat 353 / 1233 CE:
[l1] śrī ava oṃ śrīpa || subha samvat 353 śrī vā [l2] oṃ śrīyo -1-
Starting on the same line, but in the middle of the folio, a note in a different hand in hooked Nepālākṣarā:
[l1] $ oṃ namaḥ śrī vāgīsvaryai || sarasvatī mahavader irici mukhyam āśritā || paritrīm iva lokānām
On the left side of the string hole, two short notes in Nepālākṣarā:
[l2] prajyavratiṣedha, na [l3] pratyudāsa, ṛ
On the right side of the string hole, two other stanzas by the same hand as the note on the left of the string hole:
$ pradhānatvaṃ vidher yatra pratiṣedhe cāpradhānatā | pratyudāśa sa vijñeyo yatra -1- [l3] de nañ ||^^^|| aprādhānyaṃ vidher yatra pratiṣedhe cāpradhānatā | prasajyaprati-1-[l4]dhi | saujiyayā saha patanañ ||.
After this note, yet another one in a different hand in Nepālākṣarā:
[l5] $ nodāvatha mayātraś ca hīna-2-niyojayat_ [l5] navāvānasya nidhejasūtramantre-1-pralā bhavet ||
On113v, in the middle of the folio on the left side of the string hole, three verses in three different hands in Nepālākṣarā, the third corresponding (with a few scribal mistakes) to Bodhicaryāvatāra 5.94:
[l1] $ namaḥ sivāya || vipraprādākra-2-yemāśatuyakra || [l2] yakrakravijūya yeṣā kramakrakraḥ | nama bhagavateḥ |
[l3] $ nāṅgulyo kārayet kiñcid dakkiṇena tu sādaraṃ | [l4] samasteneva hastena mārgam apy evam ādiśet_ ||
Marginalia
Occasional corrections added in the top or bottom margins.

bindingDesc.p: On the inside back cover, the title (or the topic?) of the work is written in black ink (Cāndravyākaran_).

history.provenance: Bought by Prof. C. Bendall Bendall, Cecil in 1884-5.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card for admissions procedures contact Cambridge University Library Admissions).
